column1: '''Weathertop''', known in [[Sindarin]] as '''Amon Sûl''', was the southernmost top of the [[Weather Hills]]. It stood a little away from the others, and its conical top was flattened.<ref name="Knife">{{FR
Of old, it formed the boundary between [[Arthedain]] and [[Rhudaur]].
The Weather Hills lay at the centre of [[Arnor]], near the [[East Road]] that split [[Eriador]].<ref>{{RK
A tower had stood on the hill since the days of [[Elendil]], and he had stored the ''[[Palantíri
column2: palantír]]'' in its chambers. After King [[Eärendur (King of Arnor)
column3: Eärendur]] passed and the kingdom was split in three, all of his sons coveted the hill, or rather the [[Amon Sûl-stone
column4: Stone]] inside. It lay on the exact tri-state point, but eventually passed to [[Arthedain]], the realm of [[Amlaith]], the eldest son of Eärendur, although it already possessed the [[Elostirion-stone

column2: Argeleb]], the royal lines of [[Cardolan]] and [[Rhudaur]] had failed. Argeleb therefore claimed both realms as his own, hoping to reunite [[Arnor]], but the claim was resisted by Rhudaur, where the Dúnedain had dwindled and the land was now largely ruled by hillmen, who were driven by the [[Witch-king]] of [[Angmar]].

column1: As tensions with Angmar increased, Argeleb fortified his border. A great bastion arose on Weathertop, and the East Road and lower Hoarwell were fortified also. For nigh half a century, the line held, though Argeleb lost his life in battle with the Hillmen. The Witch-king did not trouble the Men, and had sent his troops further East, to [[Rivendell]]. But in {{TA
column2: 1409}}, he came forth with such a force from Angmar that no army could stop him. He razed Amon Sûl and brought its mighty walls down.<ref name="Eriador"/> [[Arveleg I
column3: Arveleg]], son of Argeleb, was slain,<ref name="TA">{{App
column4: TA}}</ref> but the Lord of the Nazgûl failed to retrieve the ''palantir''. It was secured and brought back to [[Fornost Erain]].<ref name="Eriador"/>

column1: For many centuries, the once great fortress stood in ruins on the hill. The locals paid little heed to it. It faded back into obscurity, and it was not until {{TA
column2: 3018}} the hill reappeared in the chronicles and annals. In early October, it was the scene of two fights involving the [[Nazgûl]]; one with [[Gandalf]] on [[3 October
column8: Hobbits]] avoided the main road and approached Weathertop from the north. At the top they discovered a cairn with a message from Gandalf, and spotted the [[Nazgûl
column9: Ringwraiths]] approaching in the distance along the road. That night, the Ringwraiths attacked their camp in a dell below the summit, stabbing [[Frodo Baggins
column10: Frodo]] with a [[Morgul-knife]], but were driven off by the others.<ref name="Knife"/>

:Destroying Amon Sûl is the fourth level in the ''Angmar'' campaign in ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Battle for Middle-earth II: The Rise of the Witch-king
column2: The Rise of the Witch-king]]''. The bastion is protected by five mystical Mallorn trees: one generates a solar flare that incinerates enemies, one heals damaged buildings, one creates lush Elvish pastures (that boost the Men's armor and damage), one stuns targeted enemies and one summons a battalion of archers. The mission is completed when either all five mallorns are destroyed, or the tower falls.

column1: :Additionally, two maps of Amon Sûl are available in Skirmish mode: one with the tower, which is identical to the mission save for the Mallorn trees, and one with the tower in ruins and all other buildings removed.
:Weathertop is the meeting place between [[Azog]] and his lieutenants. Azog kills [[Yazneg]] for his failue to capture or kill [[Thorin and Company]].
